captions.text: Whether they're fantasies about your crush or sweaty nightmares about being onstage in your underwear...
Dreams visit most of us almost every night.
But dreams are just a weird side effect of our brains we don't really need them right?
Think of your brain as a computer.
A computer that has to process everything you see, think, feel, and do in a day.
This computer has to stay on all the time and even when you sleep.
Dreams are proof that our brains are still working while we sleep.
Imagine this.
You're given a math problem and told not to solve it.
Instead you have to think about the problem every night before you go to sleep until you literally dream up the right answer.
Sound crazy right?!
But it can work!
In a similar experiment... researchers found that about half of the subjects had a dream about the problem.
And a quarter of those we're actually able to dream up the right answer.
*winning bell*
Not only do dreams help you problem solve, but they may be essential for learning.
In a different study... researchers found that interrupting patients during dream sleep completely stopped their learning abilities and made them a little cranky.
This is because learning depends on memory, and dreams help us form memories...
So in a world where dreams didn't exist... It's possible that you couldn't remember anything.
And therefore you'd never get better at the violin, mine-craft, taekwondo or well anything.
EVER!
So dreams are good for you.
But what about nightmares?
Ready for this?
Nightmares can actually be good for you to.
Even though they suck at the time. Once they're over your brain is left stronger and healthier.
That's because nightmares help you process intense emotions with out real life consequences
It's like dieing in a video game instead of real life.
A world where you couldn't process emotions at night could lead to a planet full of people with psychological disorders.
A lot of mood disorders like depression, PTSD, and bi-polarism are tied to abnormal dream patterns.
So think of your dreams as you're inner therapist.
They make you... well... you!
So the next time you wake up from a weird dream about running through the halls naked...
Take a moment to savor it. Just make sure it's.. actually a dream.
Sleep well.

title: What Would Happen If You Stopped Dreaming?

comments.text:
i use to dream when i was younger 5-10 yrs old now 29 including nightmares 
and were very lucid to a certain point where it felt like i was struggling 
against myself to do what i wanted like flying and not being able to 
maintain flight and be pulled to the ground repetitively. dreams were 
replaced with more nightmares which usually included me trying to save my 
family or someone in my dream i was supposed to know like a dream where 
giant cheeseburger tried to eat my grandmother or every time a light went 
out in another dream they would be skeletons when the lights came back on 
in the rooms of the hallways i was traveling or of a tiger chasing me in 
the woods until i turned into the tiger and i was chasing myself.  the 
dreams faded and were very idk murky and unclear hard to make out. I then 
had a couple premonitions as i was a bit older 17-20 one was of stepfather 
cutting his arm but i was not the first thing i remembered of my dream it 
was a game i was trying to figure out how to beat till i dreamed how and 
succeeded, which when i did the same thing in real life triggered the 
memory of my stepfather cutting his arm followed by the sound of glass 
breaking as he put it through the porch door. other was a dream of my 
stepmother in a robe like u wear in a doctors office sitting up off a metal 
table and looking at me with a smile, when i woke up it all clicked and i 
cried told my grandmother she was going to die and the next day i got a 
phone call from my father saying she had a heart attack. after that dream 
are very far in between and still usually unclear, but most of the time it 
is just black boredom and i wake up or half wake up in the darkness trying 
to make an image pop. last dream i had was about 5-6yrs ago and it was of 
all the rooms in my house rearranging themselves like a giant puzzle.﻿

comments.text:
I like my dreams, but I rarely have new ones. Usually, it's one from about 
five or six that I always have, and I can never usually remember when I 
wake up. Each one of my usual dreams has a picture that I see before it, 
kind of like seeing the cover of a movie case before you watch the movie? I 
can consciously remember the pictures, but not the dreams.

I also sometimes get those dreams that seem totally mundane and normal, but 
then they actually happen later. I wonder why those happen, since I've seen 
lots of people describing similar things so I'm obviously not the only one 
who gets those. These kinds of dreams are the only ones I remember when I 
wake up, and I've started marking down when I have the dreams and when the 
same things actually happen to me. I find it very interesting ^_^﻿
